_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION

In response to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), this PSM/RMP document has been developed for the Bongards Creameries facility located at 13200 County Road 51 in Norwood Young America, Minnesota. This document has been prepared to satisfy multiple regulations and is governed by the following agencies:

	Federal EPA's, Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r), Program 3 requirements (RMP).

	OSHAs Code of Federal Regulations, Title 29, Section 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals (PSM).

The purpose of this document is to:

	Increase the protection of public health, the environment, and facility employees by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling regulated substances.

	Assist Bongards Creameries and local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling regulated substances.

This document addresses Bongards Creameries administrative and operational programs to prevent accidents related to regulated substances and to reduce potential risks. The regulated substance of concern and focus of this document is anhydrous ammonia. The facility utilizes an ammonia system to provide refrigeration for the processing and storage of dairy products.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Bongards Creameries is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the process equipment at the facility.

Bongards Creameries senior management is not only committed to offering superior service, but also to maintaining a safety an

d environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities. Bongards Creameries safety and environmental policies as they relate to the ammonia refrigeration system are administered by the EHS Manager, Plant Manager, and Refrigeration Operator who conduct inspections of the facility to ensure compliance.

FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Bongards' Creameries is located Norwood Young America Minnesota. A 196 acre site with industrial activity / processing activity occupying approximately 3.04 acres.  Industrial activities include the manufacture and processing of natural, processed and analog cheese.  Warehouses are on site for the storage of the cheese and ingredients.

Refrigeration is necessary for the manufacture, processing and storage of dairy products. The facility maintains a refrigeration system containing approximately 11,816 pounds of anhydrous ammonia, a regulated substance. The refrigeration system, consisting of piping, valves, and equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, and then back to high pressure liquid). Typical operating conditions range from 15 psig on the low pressure side of the system to 130-180 psig on the high side.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The Bongards Creameries ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features. Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system. The facility staff conducts preventative maintenance and necessary repairs in house. An outside contractor is hired for repairs, maintenance or inspections as needed.

The facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the Uniform Mechanical Code applicable at the time of construction, which specifically outlines requirements for the safe operation of the ammonia ref

rigeration system. These safety features include ammonia sensors in the Engine Room. In addition, the majority of the ammonia is maintained inside the engine room and just outside of the engine room. All pressure vessels are equipped with pressure relief valves that are piped to several common headers and relieve to atmosphere (outside). 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

In the past 5 years there has been no releases that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Bongards Creameries has an emergency action plan in effect. The Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is detailed in the Emergency Planning and Response section of this PSM/RMP document.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:
1.)	To save lives.
2.)	To minimize and avoid injuries. 
3.)	To protect the environment.
4.)	To minimize property damage.

This Plan provides the action response organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures, which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility. This Plan is reviewed at least once per year.

In case of an ammonia emergency, the facility plans to evacuate all employees and contractors and activate the facilitys action plan to respond to the situation. If necessary, they will alert the local emergency responders (fire department) for assistance. The facility plans to coordinate emergency response efforts with the fire department on a periodic and ongoing basis.  Bongards Creameries maintains a safety committee.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Process Hazards Analysis revalidation was conducted, in conjunction with a professional ammonia refrigeration engineering contractor, in July of 2020. Recommendations resulting from the revalidation were promptly addressed. Bongards Creameries wil

l continue to provide the following.

1.	Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.
2.	Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.
3.	Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.
4.	Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.
